intro: Saccolabium carinatum, commonly known as the ridge-leaf mallow, is a perennial herb native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its hairy, lance-shaped leaves with a prominent central vein, which gives it its common name. The plant produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in summer, adding ornamental value to its habitat. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it adaptable to arid environments. Its botanical features make it a distinctive member of the Malvaceae family.
